People who grew up rich won't tell you this, but I had to fight my say here so I'm spilling all the tea. üçµ

If you invest $75 a week starting at 20 years old for 10 years, just 10 years out of your entire life, you could be financially free before 65.

Meaning you would no longer have to work for money.

But how does that work because you would have only put away $39,000.

Because you invested it and compound interest took over, the money grew - to almost $65,000 in 10 years.

And then over the next few decades it continued to grow, until it got to over $1.8M at 65.

Any extra dollar you invested would just get you to financial freedom sooner.

top_viral_videos.author: miarosemcgrath
top_viral_videos.description: Why I don‚Äôt want a rich man or a soft life üéÄ #personalfinance #financialfreedom #hypergamy
top_viral_videos.full_transcript: there is no bigger flex than a woman that has her own finances sorted. a couple years ago, I kind of got sucked into that whole world of hypergamy creators like Sarah 7, who I think is very entertaining, but that's what she is, an entertainer. this kind of rhetoric of chasing a soft life is very attractive. at the end of the day, that's all we want. freedom to kind of go to Pilates, get a matcha and have a nice time. we all want that. something that I learnt very early on in life is nothing is free. when you're financially dependent on someone, they have a say in what you do. it's like when your parents pay for your wedding, they then get a say on how it goes. and I do believe as women, we offer so much emotional labour, domestic labour, all of these different things. therefore we should be dating people that bring value to our lives. there's no doubt about that. feel like as I entered my mid twenties, but 2 I became the most financially literate I had been. and as my income doubled in the last year, I kind of realised what it felt like to have my own money. of course I already had an income, but actually make enough money where I felt financially free. that was a different feeling. almost feel like this chasing of a soft life or thinking that you're gonna get it through. a man often comes because you feel a lack of financially. if you had your finances savings in order, you probably wouldn't feel that way. if you're still in this mindset that someone else is going to do it for you, prepare for a life where you get assigned values and tasks. you trade one boss for another. I get it. the world of finance investing can seem overwhelming and like it's not meant for us. honestly, the internet has democratized this information. I urge you to take a few hours to just learn about the basics. stocks and shares, ices, emergency funds. these are all things that we should be knowing about as women. yes, it's fine to want a rich man, but I think we can also be rich women ourselves.

top_viral_videos.author: nobudgetbabe
top_viral_videos.description:
If you want to get rich in your 20s, then you need to learn from the rich people.

I went from $40k debt to a millionaire at 30, and now I'm spilling all my secrets so you can get here too.

The first thing rich people don't do is work to pay for the things they want, like the houses, cars and travel.

I just went on the most expensive vacation I've ever taken, and I didn't pay for a dollar of it out of my pocket.

Instead, I focused on buying assets like stocks and real estate that pay me while I sleep, and now that cash flow funds my lifestyle.

And this is not just "for the rich", you could buy into an apartment building for $1 by purchasing a REIT. This is one of the strategies I use, and I make 6 figures a year without working.

The second thing rich people don't do is spend time with people who don't have the life they want.

If you were trying to get sober, what do you think would happen if all your friends were heavy drinkers and spent every weekend in the bar? 

When I started hanging out with people who were making 6 figures a month, wealth became demystified. I realized when you know how money works, the amount you can make is endless.

Third thing rich people don't do is wait for shit to get bad before taking action.

Ever heard the story about how to kill a frog? 

Put a frog in boiling water, and he'll jump out right away. Put a frog in luke warm water and slowly bring it to a boil, the frog won't notice and he'll cook to death.

So many of us are in situations we say "aren't that bad", we're living paycheck to paycheck, we're in crappy jobs that don't pay our worth, we don't have money to pay our debts or buy the things we want.

Society has us in a warm water chokehold, and many people won't realize what that really means until it's too late.

Start learning how to win with money with our FREE trainings. Find them on our website under FREEBIES ‚ù§Ô∏è

The legislation is scheduled to be discussed on July 24th
top_viral_videos.full_transcript: Truth is Congress should not be here to make a buck. Congress should be here to serve the American people. There is no reason why members of Congress ought to be profiting off of the information that only they get that the rest of the American people don't get. And I don't care even if you don't have so called insider information or information not available to the public, why should members of Congress be spending their time day trading rather than focusing on the priorities that the American people sent us here to achieve and focus on? I mean, it's really simple and you don't have to explain it to anybody in America. The only people you have to explain it to are here in this building. The only people who don't seem to understand why stock trading should be banned are here in the capital. Every American gets it and they're right to get it. There is no reason why the personal profit of members of Congress should come first. It should come last. It shouldn't be a consideration at all. top_viral_videos.author: quiverquant
top_viral_videos.description: WATCHING THIS ONE‚Ä¶ üßê #quiverquant #geopolitics #stocks #finance #learnontiktok #norway #fyp
top_viral_videos.full_transcript: people are up in arms after photos broke yesterday showing the terrible conditions of a cobalt mine in the Congo. of course, the irony here is that a lot of cobalt, along with many other materials powering the Green Revolution, are often sourced from places like this with little regard for environmental or labor loss. the reason I'm telling you this is that while all this was going on, a report came out of Norway that went largely ignored by the media, in which they announced they found a substantial amount of rare earth minerals on their seabed. many of which are currently being sourced from places like the cobalt mine and the Congo I mentioned earlier. and here's the catch. they estimated to have found so how much is that? let's do some quick math. the current market rate of cobalt is about 21 Ôø°1. multiply that by 31 million tons, that cobalt is worth 13 trillion, give or take, or 3 times norway's total GDP. now, of course, if Nor were to extract all that cobalt, it would be worth far less than 13 trillion dollars because they'd flood the market with it. but nevertheless, when you consider all the other materials they found and how much of it, it's difficult to ignore the deep sea mining opportunity laying under the ocean. now, here's where I ran into some issues. there's only a few deep sea mining stocks and none of them have been able to commercialize yet, so they're all bleeding money. I was about to give up, then I came across as CEO of a deep sea mining company with the ticker TMC that has been buying shares of his own company recently. this intrigued me so I started researching them more. and that's when I noticed that tmc's second and if you don't know, the reason that this is such a big deal is because Maersk is the largest container shipping company in the world by tonnage and All Seas is a major offshore construction company. in fact, they both have major share positions in TMC. a company that has almost 0 ceiling as far as economic and environmental benefits. along with the CEO buying shares all while the company is down 90 percent from its IPO. it makes me wonder if there's more than meets the eye with TMC. this might be more of a lottery ticket than an investment, but what do you guys think? in the meantime, to see what stocks politicians, hedge funds, and Ceos are buying, check out Quiverquant. and until next time.

top_viral_videos.author: nobudgetbabe
top_viral_videos.description:
They don't have your money, they don't have any money.

The US is just 10 years away from a full blown retirement crisis, where the people who have been paying into social security their entire lives might just not get anything, with benefits expected to be cut as early as 2034.

People are getting ready to retire, wondering where their money is, and it's not there.

And if they had invested that money on their own instead of giving it to the government, they could easily be retiring with millions.

If instead of paying 6.2% of your pay into Social Security, you put that into the stock market, let's say you were making $60k a year, you'd have over $2.6M. That would provide you with $100,000 a year in income for the rest of your life. You probably could have even retired early.

Now that social security will fully run out of money in 2037, a few options they're considering are raising the retirement age because 65 is too young, or they're considering just scrapping the program altogether.

You can't depend on anyone to take care of you in this life but yourself, and we've been lied to about what retirement is. It's not an age, it's a number in the bank.
top_viral_videos.full_transcript: this is so incredibly concerning for every single person that lives in the US not only do they not have your money they don't have any money and now the US is just 10 years away from a full blown retirement crisis for people who have been paying into Social Security for their entire lives are going to see their benefits cut starting in 2034 with Social Security expected to fully run out by 2037 like people are getting ready to retire wondering where their money is and it's not there and one of the most horrendous parts of this is that if these people hadn't have given their money to the government for Social Security they could easily be retiring with millions of dollars so with Social Security you contribute about 6.2% of your paycheck into this fund so let's say instead of putting that money into Social Security you put that into the stock market you're paying 6.2% of your paycheck you're making $60,000 a year you could retire with over $2.6 million this $2.6 million could have provided you with over $100,000 a year in income and perpetuity for the rest of your life however long you lived and you honestly probably could have even retired early based on this sum now people are looking at retiring with nothing that they have put into this fund and the proposed solution some of them are to just scrap the program entirely altogether just get rid of it and another proposed solution is to just change the age of retirement because apparently 65 is too young this is why I say you cannot depend on anyone in this life to take care of you you and this is why I also say that we have been lied to okay they want you to think retirement is an age retirement is 65 or now retirement is 70 no retirement is a number in the bank don't just get to retire when you're 65 as we have seen from this you get to retire when you have enough money to cover your expenses if you wanna learn more about how to do this check our link in bio

I like it because it is user-friendly, you can trade options like I doü§≠. You can buy shares, and you can even trade futures! All of the features that you would need for basic investment can be found on one singular platform.  

Let me know in the comments if you love Webull too! üíô

Disclaimer: By using any links in this video, I may receive a commission. This comes at no additional cost to you, and it allows me to continue to provide value on this community. I am not a financial advisor. This is not financial advice nor am I recommending any investments. All information in this video is for entertainment purposes only. Sierra Smith (‚ÄúAffiliate‚Äù) is compensated by Webull Financial LLC (‚ÄúWebull‚Äù) member of FINRA and SIPC. Investing involves risk. More info at webull.com/disclosures. Options are risky and not suitable for all investors. Investors can rapidly lose 100% or more of their investment trading option. Before trading options, carefully read Characteristics and Risks of Standardized Options, available at Webull.com/policy.
top_viral_videos.full_transcript: Hey y'all, it's Sierra and if you've ever wanted to start investing or trading options, here's exactly how to do it with weebull. Step 1 you're gonna go to my bio, click the link, and download the weebull app. Step 2 is sign up for a brokerage account. It only takes a couple minutes and it may take a day or two to get approved, but once you get that email, you're in. If you want to trade options like I do, taking single leg calls and puts, make sure you apply for a level 2 account. Step 3 which is the fun part. Get it? Fun funds is fund your account. You can start with as little as $50 $100. I don't know why people think that you need thousands of dollars to start. You don't. Plus I heard you might be able to get some free stocks. You didn't hear it from me though. Now once you're in, here's exactly what I do. I open the app and I head straight to my watch list. This is where I keep all the stocks that I'm tracking for the week. If I'm curious about something new, I just hit the search bar and pull it up. When I'm ready to trade, I just choose my stock and we will shows me all the options contracts available. It's super beginner friendly. Just a few taps and I'm in. One of my favourite tools, the markets tab, because here you can Check futures, trade shares, and even practice with paper trading. So if you're not ready to risk real money yet, don't practice with fake money in real time until you feel confident. So if you're ready to finally start trading, or if you just want to learn, click the link in my bio and give weebull a try. I might be biased, but hey, you might love it just as much as I do.

Benefits of Custodial Roth IRAs include:
‚Ä¢ Tax-free withdrawals in retirement.
‚Ä¢ Compound interest over many years.
‚Ä¢ Instills good saving habits in minors.
‚Ä¢ Teaches investing and financial responsibility.
‚Ä¢ Minors can contribute if they have earned income.
‚Ä¢ No required minimum distributions during the account holder's lifetime.
‚Ä¢ Allows for a smooth wealth transfer to the minor at adulthood.
‚Ä¢ The account is established for a minor, typically someone under the age of 18 or 21, depending on state laws.

top_viral_videos.full_transcript: I went to school for finance, and I worked on Wall Street. And one of the biggest things I Learned on Wall Street is that I got exposed to that information in my 20s. Wishing I got exposed to it when I was a baby. Now I have a niece. She's the next generation. When she was born, the moment she got a Social Security number, I opened a brokerage account for her. Because I remember being on Wall Street and watching them open brokerage accounts the moment their kids were born. I remember looking at college students, the children of the billionaires we serviced. I remember seeing them live off their dividend portfolios. Right? So instead of feeling like I was behind, I felt like the moment my niece was born, I got a head start. When you open an investment account for a child, you need your social. You need their Social Security number. You need your Social Security number. You need their birthday, their address. She's absolutely right. Kids have a lot of time to compound their wealth. Guys, if you invest five to six hundred dollars a month, by the time they're 18 years old, they'll have around a quarter million dollars from average stock market returns. Follow to see my videos where I can show a step by step tutorial on how to set this up.

top_viral_videos.description: are you ‚Äòfrugal chic‚Äô? #savingmoney #personalfinance #splurgevssave
top_viral_videos.full_transcript: the frugal Chic who is she on the surface she appears very luxurious but underneath it all she is very savvy about her money so these are five things that characterise the Frugal Chic No. 1 she makes inexpensive items look luxurious her friends are always asking her where is this from and she says it's from vintage Zara and they're shocked she makes it look expensive it's her aura number two she walks absolutely everywhere if she can walk somewhere she will that ¬£1 75 from the bus may not seem like a lot but that's ¬£1 75 that she doesn't wanna spend on tfl No. 3 she has an eclectic personal style that was built over time she realises that she can't buy her way into a subculture or an aesthetic these things are curated and collected over time for example she doesn't need the latest bag charm trend she has one from five years ago from when she went on holiday the key is no one else has it No. 4 even though she loves her iced matchas iced lattes she will not be buying one every single day it's not a need it's a want she'd rather make it at home or have it at work No. 5 the frugal chic is actually not afraid to say no and she knows her values while other people call her grandma she will not be spending ¬£400 on a night out yes she still goes out to bars sees friends at this point she's accepted that she's a little bit of a homebody but that doesn't make her boring she has other hobbies so those are five things that characterise the frugal chic do you think this sounds like you let me know in the comments below

top_viral_videos.full_transcript: Congress is a rich man's club. That's the problem. That's what we're trying to fix. I would suspect that I probably have the fewest assets of anybody sitting on this dias. I am not a rich man, unlike those to my left. So, I mean, listen, the American people look at people like the former speaker of the house, who makes better returns than anybody in America. They look at senators who were investigated during the COVID pandemic for their miraculous stock trades, and they say, how is this possible? To think that this might become a problem in the future is, frankly, fanciful. It's a problem now. It is. And it's not just in perception. It is reality. Members of Congress are trading daily based on information that the public doesn't have. And now we've heard the insider trading. I understand that insider trading is banned, but let's be honest. Members of Congress get information that is technically not insider information. Is defined by the securities laws, that is nevertheless extremely beneficial to know. And often we get it earlier than other people.

top_viral_videos.author: _itsornella
top_viral_videos.description:
What are some of investment platforms you've used and loved? I've used a few investment platforms to date and my favs are @bettermenthq and @robinhoodapp because of how easy they make investing for beginners! Being able to auto invest with Betterment has particularly allowed me to grow my investments because the platform is doing all of the work for me.

#investingforbeginners #investingexplained #investingtips #financialfreedom #moneytok #wealthbuilding #moneymanagement
top_viral_videos.full_transcript: I'm gonna rate all of the investment platforms that I've used to date as a girly who is investing to become a millionaire by 45. Number one, Charles Schwab. I would give this a three and a half out of five. This is a really good place if you are someone who wants to build your own portfolios. You kind of know what you're doing investment wise, and you want to be able to purchase stocks and do all of that in one place. Charles Schwab is a great brokerage account to do so. They give you a lot of autonomy to build your own portfolios. But for some people who have no idea what they're doing, this can actually be a little overwhelming. Um, and that's actually why I ended up moving my money from them. Not because I couldn't manage my own money, but because I didn't want to. And I didn't want to go in and have to purchase my own investments on a monthly basis. Number two, betterment. This is a 5 out of five for me. This is where all of my investments are now. I have my I R A. With them. I have my sub I R A. With them. I have my general brokerage accounts with them. It is just so easy to use betterment as an investment vehicle. I love the fact that it is automated for you, but you still have some customization in terms Of the blend of your portfolio and how you ultimately structure it. But I love the fact that they will do all of the investing for you. I just need to set a certain amount each month. Out of sight, out of mind. Love that there are other robo advisors that do this as well. Wellfleet is one of them. So you can use either of these interchangeably. But betterment has been my investment platform of choice. I was one of the early adopters of Robinhood. I was on that platform since 2016 2017, and I was getting all my friends, whoever would listen to me, I was telling them to invest on Robinhood. I like how Robinhood is a very gamified way of investing. They give you a lot of information on their platform that helps. Um, I deduct a point because, again, similar to Charles Schwab, you really are out in the open, investing on your own. And for some people who don't know what they're doing, that can be overwhelming. Also, this could be good or bad, depending on how you view it and what your investment strategies are. But they very easily allow you to, uh, participate in options trading, margin trading, all of those things. And for people who are not familiar with investing and don't really know what they're doing, this can be dangerous. So the gamified aspect of it makes that kind of Investment easier for people who understand what they're doing. But if you do not, it can become a very slippery slope, and it can trend very closely towards gambling. You do Vanguard Fidelity interchangeably? Because I've had them for, like, work for one K's and that kind of stuff. I don't really like their user interface. So three and a half out of five. They give you the same thing as Charles Schwab, kind of, but I think their user interfaces are a little dated. We're having all of my work for Owen K's and all of that, it was a little clunky. So I would give Vanguard and Fidelity three and a half out of five. What investment platforms do you use and love and, you know, feel like you wanna share with the group?

top_viral_videos.description: Have you ever referred a friend to a job?? #money #work #career #job #office #pay #interview #resume #corporate #bff #friend #networking #tech #business #greenscreen
top_viral_videos.full_transcript: one of my smartest friends just tried to cold apply for a job at google and I all but smacked the laptop out of his hands to prevent him from making this huge mistake you'd never do that though because you follow me vivian your rich bff and your favorite wall street girly who's gonna let you in on this career secret never apply for a job blindly always seek a referral from someone at the company before you submit an application. And I know you're thinking - I don't know anybody who works there you don't need to before you submit a job application go to LinkedIn and search the company you wanna work at  once you're there you're gonna go to the people tab it'll then show your friends people from your school people in your area and second and third degree connections that work at that company then you just dm them and ask them to refer you why would anyone do that for you?!  to get paid duh at most companies when an employee refers someone who ends up getting hired they'll get a bonus and if the referral doesn't get hired there aren't any consequences for that employee so reach out having a referral will significantly increase your chances of getting that first interview which is usually the hardest step!!
